content: Both the internals forum and the users forum have terms of service that state they're licensed under CC-by-nc-sa. This is not at all ideal, as it isn't an Open Source license, and it means people shouldn't be copying anything from forum posts into code/documentation/rfcs/etc. We should, ideally, get this changed to the Rust license: MIT OR Apache-2.0.
We can't retroactively change the license for old posts, but we could state that all new posts after YYYY-MM-DD are under the new license.

(We could also, optionally, see how hard it would be to track a concept of "I agree with the new licensing" to user profiles, or we could just not worry about it for old posts and track it on a case-by-case basis if people want to copy things from old posts.)

You could also do a mix of the two. Say that after X date posts are under a different licence and use the forum post as a place where people can volunteer to re-licence their old posts. This would probably cover most of the content on the discourse forums.
this is already in the core team's radar, and we discussed it a couple of times already
we have a snippet from mozilla legal, but we're still doing a bit of back-and-forth to polish it up
cc @nikomatsakis @Carol (Nichols || Goulding)

@Josh Triplett will do
We were planning to do a date-based split
Do you have a strong opinion about (e.g.) CC BY 3.0 versus "MIT/Apache2"
I would ideally prefer the MIT OR Apache-2.0 dual-license, so that when people post pre-RFCs or documentation or proposals or similar, that content can make its way into Rust repositories.

Otherwise, if (for instance) someone posted a pre-RFC and someone else picked it up and ran with it, there'd be licensing issues unless we tracked down the original pre-RFC author (and anyone else who posted content that got copied/quoted/etc).

If someone picks up the text of a pre-RFC and then runs with it, under MIT terms don't you still need to list the license from the first poster and then add the license of the next poster, and so on?

Re-listing all the authors and listing the MIT license over and over is the worst part of the MIT license.
@Lokathor Only if they attach an explicit copyright notice.
MIT requires preserving copyright notices; if there aren't any, then it's trivial to do so. :)
a fair loophole

Josh Triplett said:

I would ideally prefer the MIT OR Apache-2.0 dual-license, so that when people post pre-RFCs or documentation or proposals or similar, that content can make its way into Rust repositories.

yeah so I'm scheduling a call with someone at moz legal. probably not an issue.

So I got approval for this language

User contributions after [Insert Date] are dual-licensed under the MIT and Apache 2.0 licenses unless otherwise stated. The licenses were explicitly chosen to ensure that text from comments on this forum may be included in RFCs, which are also licensed in the same fashion, per RFC 2044. This license also implies that code snippets can be incorporated into the Rust repository (or other repositories using a similar license).

User contributions before [Insert Date] are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License. Without limiting any of those representations or warranties, Mozilla has the right (though not the obligation) to, in Mozilla’s sole discretion (i) refuse or remove any content that, in Mozilla’s reasonable opinion, violates any Mozilla policy or is in any way harmful or objectionable, or (ii) terminate or deny access to and use of the Website to any individual or entity for any reason, in Mozilla’s sole discretion. Mozilla will have no obligation to provide a refund of any amounts previously paid.
which I think fits what everybody wants

Two things:
1) If it wouldn't require massive re-approval, would it be possible to change "in RFCs" to "in RFCs and code/comments"?
2) We should, separate from this statement, have a forum thread for "please copy/paste the following statement if you're willing to relicense your past comments".
yes I think (1) is fine
and (2) is a fine idea too

@Josh Triplett how about this

User contributions after [Insert Date] are dual-licensed under the MIT and Apache 2.0 licenses unless otherwise stated. The licenses were explicitly chosen to ensure that text from comments on this forum may be included in RFCs, which are also licensed in the same fashion, per RFC 2044. This license also implies that content from the comments on this forum (including code snippets) can be incorporated into the rust-lang/rust repository (or other repositories using a similar license).
That's perfect, thank you.

I guess -- one thing we should check -- is what kind of notice (if any) we need to give. Is there some "implicit acceptance" that's fine? Do we need to, say, post an announcement with 30 days notice? I don't know what the legal requirements are

Yeah I wanted to think about the roll-out -- I don't thikn there's a "legal requirement" per se but I think we sohuld post an announcement saying that "as of this date in 2 weeks" or something, this takes effect.
this is all basically a purely theoretical concern anyway
Indeed.
Updated and announced.
@nikomatsakis Do you plan to make a past-posts-relicensing thread, or should I?
Oh, I forgot about that. Currently dealing with the feedback from users forum.
Sigh.
I think whoever posted the comment suggesting to set a name or similar to indicate different licensing was making a mistake. The way to opt out of the licensing is "don't post".
You don't have to grant license over your old posts, but I don't think we should be permitting any new posts with restrictive licensing.

(Also, the whole "you can't post snippets of code under some other license" problem existed before, if someone posted any code at all under a license that required attribution, or code under a license that doesn't allow adding restrictions.)
It's worth clarifying that nobody is giving up copyrights here, though.

Also, with the benefit of hindsight, we perhaps could have phrased the message more clearly: the old ToS didn't allow using post content under an Open Source license, the new one does. That would reduce the fixation on commercial use. But it's too late for that now.

Should it be allowed to post a cost block example under an alternate license if an explicit comment is given in that code block?
eg:

// Copyright FooOrg, GPL3
fn my_fun() { ... }
@Lokathor I don't think we should go there, if we don't absolutely have to. There are plenty of places to post code.
If it’s important you can always use a gist which can include a separate licence file with the code.
What @XAMPPRocky says, if people are absolutely dead set, they can just link remote code. We shouldn't bother about that kind complexity.
